Content/Script: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name] here. Saw you reached out about [Address]. Is now a bad time?
Coaching Notes: ASKING "Is now a bad time?" gets better responses than "Do you have time?" People feel safer saying "no" than committing to "yes." Gives them control of the conversation.

Content/Script:
Hi [Name], this is [Lead Manager First Name]. I just texted you - did you get it?

[If yes] Great. I saw you reached out about [Address]. It seems like you might be exploring your options?

[Listen for response]

What's got you thinking about selling [Address]?
Coaching Notes: START WITH "It seems like..." to show you understand their situation (makes them feel heard). Then ask "What's got you thinking about selling?" instead of yes/no questions - forces them to open up and tell you what's really going on.

Content/Script:
SUBJECT: [Name] - [Address]

Hi [Name],

I'm [Lead Manager First Name]. Just tried calling you about [Address].

It sounds like you might be weighing your options on what to do with the property.

I work with homeowners in [Neighborhood] who are in similar situations - some need to sell quickly, some just want to know what it's worth, some are testing the waters.

What makes the most sense for you right now?

No pressure either way.

[Lead Manager First Name]
[Lead Manager Phone]
Coaching Notes: ACKNOWLEDGE different scenarios they might be in (shows empathy). Ask "What makes sense for you?" instead of pitching - makes them articulate their needs. End with "No pressure" to create safety.

Content/Script:
CALL: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name] again. I tried you earlier. Is this still a bad time?

[If they answer] It seems like you've been tough to reach - I'm guessing you're pretty busy?

VOICEMAIL: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name] with REI Team. Look, I know you're probably getting bombarded with calls about [Address]. I get it - that must be overwhelming.

Here's what I'm NOT going to do: I'm not going to bug you every day or pressure you into something that doesn't make sense for you.

What I CAN do: Give you a straight answer on what we can offer and let you decide if it makes sense.

If now's not the right time, no problem. My number is [Lead Manager Phone].

Talk soon.
Coaching Notes: CALL OUT their concerns BEFORE they say them ("I know you're getting bombarded..."). This disarms objections and shows you get it. Removes pressure by acknowledging what they're thinking.

Content/Script: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. Haven't connected yet. Is the timing just not right?
Coaching Notes: ASKING "Is the timing just not right?" makes it easy for them to respond without feeling pressured. They can say "yeah, bad timing" and keep the door open.

Content/Script:
Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. Still trying to connect with you about [Address]. Are you avoiding me?

[If they laugh/respond] It seems like maybe the timing just hasn't been right?

[If no answer] I'll try again later - no pressure.
Coaching Notes: USE HUMOR to break tension ("Are you avoiding me?" makes them laugh). Keep it light. NO VOICEMAIL - research shows 3+ voicemails decrease response rates. Only leaving 2 total VMs (Day 0 and Day 11).

Content/Script:
SUBJECT: What makes us different (probably not what you think)

Hi [Name],

You've probably heard from a bunch of "we buy houses" companies by now.

I'm guessing some of them sounded too good to be true?

Here's the truth: We're not going to offer you retail value. Nobody who buys cash can.

What we CAN offer:
→ A real number in 24 hours (not "maybe" or "we'll see")
→ Close on YOUR timeline (7 days or 60 days - you pick)
→ Zero repairs, zero fees, zero BS

The question is: Does that make sense for what you need right now?

If it doesn't, I totally get it. Listing with an agent might be the better move.

But if speed and simplicity matter more than squeezing every last dollar, let's talk.

What sounds more important to you - max price or fast/easy?

[Lead Manager First Name]
Coaching Notes: ADDRESS "too good to be true" concern upfront. BE HONEST: "We won't offer retail" builds massive trust. Then force them to think about what matters more - max price or speed/simplicity?

Content/Script: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. Wrong number?
Coaching Notes: HUMOR breaks the pattern of ignored texts. "Wrong number?" makes them respond "No, right number but..." and suddenly they're talking to you.

Content/Script:
Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name] with REI Team. I feel like I might be bothering you at this point?

[Listen]

It seems like you might still be thinking it over?

[If no answer, don't leave VM - just note the attempt]
Coaching Notes: LABEL how they might be feeling ("I feel like I might be bothering you") - shows self-awareness and empathy. NO VOICEMAIL on this call - save VMs for Day 0 and Day 11 only.

Content/Script:
SUBJECT: You're probably thinking...

Hi [Name],

You're probably thinking one of these:

1. "This sounds like a lowball"
2. "I need to talk to my family first"
3. "I'm not sure I'm ready to sell"
4. "I want to see what a realtor says"

All totally valid.

Here's what I've learned working with homeowners in [Neighborhood]:

The people who sell to us are usually in one of these situations:
→ They inherited a property they don't want
→ They're tired of being a landlord
→ The house needs work they can't afford or don't want to deal with
→ They need to sell fast (divorce, relocation, financial pressure)

Does any of that sound familiar?

If not - if you have time and the house is in great shape - you'll probably get more money listing it traditionally.

But if you're in one of those situations above, we might be able to help.

What's really going on with [Address]?

[Lead Manager First Name]
Coaching Notes: LIST every objection they're probably thinking ("You're probably thinking..."). Then describe common situations they might relate to. End with "What's really going on?" to get them to open up.

Content/Script: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. Straight question - are we even in the ballpark of what you need?
Coaching Notes: DIRECT question forces them to evaluate if you're a fit. "Are we even in the ballpark?" is honest and makes them think - not pushy.

Content/Script:
Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. I'm going to try you one more time, then I'll leave you alone. Fair?

[If answer] It seems like [Address] might not be urgent for you right now?

[If no answer, don't leave VM]
Coaching Notes: ACKNOWLEDGE you've been calling but keep it light. "Fair?" gets them to engage. NO VOICEMAIL - limiting to 2 total VMs (Day 0 and Day 11 only) per research.

Content/Script:
SUBJECT: What selling traditionally ACTUALLY costs

Hi [Name],

Let's talk about the elephant in the room.

You're probably thinking: "If I list with a realtor, I'll get more money."

And you might be right.

But here's what that actually looks like:

Say [Address] is worth $300k:
→ 6% realtor commission: -$18,000
→ Closing costs (2-3%): -$7,500
→ Repairs from inspection: -$5,000 to $20,000
→ Staging/photos: -$2,000
→ Time on market: 60-90 days
→ Mortgage/taxes/insurance while it sits: -$3,000+

Net after all that: ~$265,000
Time invested: 3-4 months

With us:
→ Offer: $260,000
→ Your costs: $0
→ Time to close: 10 days

So the question isn't "who pays more."

The question is: What's worth more to you - an extra $5,000 or 3 months of your life?

That's not a trick question. For some people, the answer is "give me the $5k."

For others, it's "I just want this handled."

Which one sounds like you?

[Lead Manager First Name]
Coaching Notes: ADDRESS the "list for more money" objection head-on with REAL MATH. Concrete numbers build credibility. Then ask "Which one sounds like you?" to force self-reflection on priorities.

Content/Script: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. What would have to be true for us to help with [Address]?
Coaching Notes: POWERFUL QUESTION: "What would have to be true for us to help?" Makes them articulate their exact criteria. Once they tell you, you know exactly what they need.

Content/Script:
CALL: Hi [Name], [Lead Manager First Name]. Last call, I promise. It seems like this just isn't the right fit?

VOICEMAIL: Hey [Name], [Lead Manager First Name] here.

This is my last call. I don't want to be a pest.

I just closed on a house on [Nearby Street] last week. The homeowner was in a similar spot - inherited property, needed repairs, didn't want to deal with it.

We closed in 8 days. No inspections, no appraisals, no drama.

They told me afterward: "I should've called you two months ago. I wasted so much time stressing about this."

I don't know if that's you. Maybe [Address] is different.

But if you're avoiding this because it feels overwhelming, I get it.

What if it could be easier than you think?

Text me if you want to talk. If not, I won't bug you again.

[Lead Manager Phone]
Coaching Notes: SHARE a real recent example (social proof). Then say "I don't know if that's you" (low pressure). End with "What if it could be easier than you think?" to reframe their perspective. Final call.

Content/Script:
SUBJECT: Can I close your file?

Hi [Name],

I've been trying to reach you for two weeks.

That tells me something:

Either:
a) You're not interested
b) You already handled [Address]
c) The timing just isn't right
d) I'm saying something wrong and turning you off

If it's A or B - congrats, glad it worked out. I'll close your file.

If it's C - if you think you might want to sell in 3-6 months but not now - just reply "later" and I'll check back with you then.

If it's D - if I've been too pushy or said something that rubbed you the wrong way - I apologize. That wasn't my intention.

But here's what I don't want to happen:

Six months from now, your situation with [Address] gets worse. Maybe the property taxes hit, or the HOA comes after you, or a pipe bursts, or a tenant trashes the place.

And you think: "Damn, I should've called that guy back."

I've seen it happen.

So here's my ask:

Even if now isn't the right time, save my number.

Because if things change - if you suddenly NEED to sell fast - I'm still here.

I had a homeowner ignore me for 6 months. Then her tenant destroyed the place. She called me back in a panic.

We gave her an offer in 24 hours and closed in 5 days.

She told me: "Thank God you didn't give up on me."

I'm not giving up on you either.

But I AM going to stop calling.

The ball's in your court.

[Lead Manager First Name]
[Lead Manager Phone]

P.S. - If you respond "not interested," I'll respect that and you'll never hear from me again. No hard feelings.
Coaching Notes: LIST every possible reason for no response. PAINT a picture of future regret ("6 months from now...") - people fear loss more than they value gain. Share real story of someone who waited too long. End with "Ball's in your court" - final control moment.

Content/Script: Change Status to "Nurture - Uncontacted". Add to monthly email sequence. Note: Used full Chris Voss cadence. If they respond in future, they're highly qualified - they've been thinking about it.
Coaching Notes: END ACTIVE CADENCE: They've experienced empathy, honesty, and options. If they come back later, they're highly qualified - they've been thinking about it. Move to monthly nurture emails.
